prompt: Write a poem about underpass echo in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
The Underpass Murmorlax

Under the road of shivercrete,
the dripple-drips go flitterflow;
Graffiferns curl in diesel heat,
and underbellow answers low.

Pigeons clack in the clangerglass,
lamplings sweat a sodium snow;
Boot-lap, boot-lap across the pass,
and every foot is echoed so.

“There lurks the Murmorlax,” they say,
“it gulps your shout and spits it twice;
It nests in arches cold and gray,
with ribby grin and guardrail-vice.”

I took my thrumstick, trembling proud,
my hushnet wound with silver twine;
I whistled thin through fumes and cloud
to catch its copy-catty whine.

Long-long I stalked the rumble-gloom,
by dripledger and puddlepond;
I tasted fog like tin and broom,
and heard boomloops from far beyond.

Then out it slid from tunnel’s throat—
the Murmorlax with neon eyes!
Its echo-lappet fetched my note
and flung it back in doubled size.

Its jaws were ribbed with rebar-gnash,
its belly drummed a railcar roll;
It slither-swayed in splash and splash,
and shadow-milked my little soul.

I cracked my thrumstick—bangaroo!—
and cast the hushnet wide and round;
The reverbsnare went ringaloo,
and snipped the copies from the sound.

The Murmorlax grew thin as mist,
its boomloop shrank to pebble-tap;
It fizzled down my netted wrist
and curled into a paper-cup.

O hoor-a-hey! the tunnel hushed,
the dripple-drips fell one by one;
Graffilume stars in puddles blushed,
and quietly, the night moved on.

Now under road and shivercrete,
where skittercars go thunderflow,
Mind what you murmur with your feet—
for underpass remembers so.

prompt: Write a poem about morning fog in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
Fogswoggle Morn

The dampy dawn went drozzle-dim,
and lane and lark lay muffled-slow;
The hedges wore a snuffle-brim,
the murklemist went swarfing low.

"Mind now," said Gran with knurly thumb,
"shun Fogswoggle that fuzzles road;
It gloams your wits to glutchy numb—
pack kettle-spark to share the load."

I strapped my sunspoon to my side,
my glimber-lamp, my weatherblade;
With pocket-pep and stridey stride,
I slipped along the hedgerade.

The gateposts grew all fizzle-faint,
the milestones mumbled, "who?" and "where?"
A gloamlet breathed a milky paint
and swizzled round the bramble-stair.

It swurled and sworfed, a floonish fog,
a snorfle-wreath with nullish grin;
"Come sip," it cooed, "the dreamywog;
unsee the world and wander in."

I popped my kettle—plink and flare!—
and swirled the gloom with sunspoon light;
The murk slid smooring back to lair,
dringsome-thin and mild of fright.

Then up the lane the thrushes sprang,
the roofs grew crisp with chimbley-glee;
I ran to Gran with jangly clang—
"Oh skybliss-day! Huroo! Huree!"

And Gran, she twinkled, bright and snug:
"Well played, my sprat, you dewdrop-brave!
Now fill the kettle, fix a mug—
for fog will flindle back to lave."

prompt: Write a poem about déjà vu in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
The Againwyrm

Blinksome the afterlight did glaze,
and sniddle reeds went smee;
the hedgerows smelled of almost-days
and tickle-tockled me.

I paused at stones that winked in twain,
at gates of once-before;
my heart went round the roundagain
and tapped a once-a-more.

Old Gramfer brewed his kettle-tale:
“Mind loopsome beasts that woo—
where crossroads crease the nowish vale,
the Againwyrm finds you.”

I hefted up a nownot blade,
a keen remember-steel;
and down the turn-and-turning glade
I crept on echo-heel.

The hedges blurred; the hourbells spun;
the sky turned déjà-blue;
twice-started sun unstarted, then
began beginning too.

There round the bend it rounded twice—
the Againwyrm, loop-grim;
with clockscale hide and twizzle eyes
and breath of steeped-machine.

It sissed, “We meet as met we met,”
through dew and rustling yew;
its tail stitched up the wagon-rut
and knotted noon to noon.

I struck the already-place I knew—
the pre-scar on its chin;
the blade went once, went once anew,
went not, then once again.

It folded up its circle-self,
unraveling its hue;
the hedgerows clapped their leafy pelf
for yester-now made new.

I hauled the maybe-muzzled thing
through lanes of when-again;
and Gramfer piped a kettle-hymn:
“Well rung, you cleft the skein!”

Blinksome the afterlight yet glazed,
and sniddle reeds went smee;
the hedgerows hummed of almost-ways—
had we not been? Had we?

prompt: Write a poem about desire path in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
The Wantway

’Twas breezly on the meadow-marge,
The bramblewhicks did sway;
The mown-lawn dozed in checker-charge,
And signs said, Keep the Way.

“Beware the Shortcut-Snick, my sprout,
The planners’ prim array;
Trust only grids and granite routes,
And keep to lawful way.”

He buckled up his brambleshoes,
His scuff-stick swung for play;
He pocketed a crumbly map
And sniffed the skimmer-day.

He paused where stone-made footpaths bent
Through bureaucrust and clay;
A hush said, Make a softer curve—
Desire-path wants a way.

He scuffled through the velvet-sward
With shuff and squidge and splay;
A faintling stripe, a slinkweft seam,
Unraveled green to gray.

The Pavewights hissed, “Not there, not there!”
Clipboards in brackish gray;
He doffed his hat and hummed, “Now then—
It’s wishcut time today.”

Then joggers, dogs, and dapperbees
Came zig and zag to play;
Their footfalls, plock by plocket-plock,
Beat out the wantway’s way.

Yet mind the moss and beetlefolk—
Step light where shadows lay;
Desire is best when gentle-soled,”
The dappled breezes say.

The grass ungreened to honest earth,
A tawny thread of yay;
A throughline, simple, true as thirst—
A path that chose to stay.

Back home he came, galumph and grin,
Across the wantway’s lay;
“O flumptious day! Caloo! Calay!”
They jigged a jig-of-May.

poem:
The Boardrumph

Under buzzglow hummed the ceiling-bars,
And swivel-wheels went whisher-weep;
The glassboard wore its marker-scars,
While coffee-cups in murmur sleep.

All metric-mild, the note-folk drooped,
As minute-mites crept slide-by-slide;
Agenda-leaves in loop-lings looped,
And socket-breaths through carpet sighed.

“Take heed, my spriven sprout,” said Ma,
“The Boardrumph haunts this confer-gloom—
With KPI-claws and budget-jaw,
It stalks the glassy-windowed room.

Its deadline-thrash, its pivot glare,
Will blanch the bravest status-breath;
The Scopeydove will widen air,
The Quibblewasp will nag to death.”

He gripped his Agenda-blade full tight,
His Point-lance blinked a laser-beam;
He timeboxed up his courage-light
And stepped into the huddle-dream.

Through fluorogloom and nametag mist,
Past cord-tangles and pastry-crumb,
He heard a clicker-clack—then hissed
The Boardrumph from the whiteboard-plum.

It came with budget-breath so stale,
And spreadsheets in its gristle-mane;
Its inbox-eyes went pewter-pale—
He met it in the swivel-lane.

Click-clack! went Point-lance, ping and pat;
The Agenda-blade went riddle-rake;
He parried jargon, bluffed its chat,
And split its scope with candor-flake.

Back to the chart he bore the news,
And set the minutes right and bright:
“O hurrah-glow, you quarterly muse—
We’ve wrangled sense from meeting-blight!”

The buzzglow purred in ceiling-bars,
Soft swivel-wheels went whisher-weep;
The glassboard shed its ghostly scars,
And coffee found a quieter sleep.

poem:
The Clavichortle Room

At snorble-hour the timbrelings
Went twiddle in the room;
The cobble-keys on ivorings
Made glimmer-gong and bloom.

Beware the Brumble-bass, my sprout;
Shun clangly crash-a-phones;
Grip tight your baton, tune about,
And pack your metronomes.

Wear mufflewool on tender ears,
Rosin your fiddle-stick;
Let courage hum between your gears,
Keep time: tik-tok-a-tik.

He crept into the musicroom,
Where standerlings were stacked;
The shaggy drum went boomble-boom,
The clarigleams all quacked.

The Clavichortle grinned its grin,
With teeth of onyx keys;
It giggled through the lid-sprung chin
In tinkly-minor breeze.

Then brumbled up the Brumble-bass
From f-hole, bow, and bout;
The Snickelsnare with copper face
Went ratta-tat about.

He raised his stick—ho! hush the din—
And drew a steady line;
With do-re-meh and grinny-grin,
He set the beats to time.

Fortissquee! then piano-peep!
Staccatapult and glide!
He circled rests to coax them sleep,
Let leggaroons abide.

The wobbuloons ceased wob-a-ling,
The timbrelings took tea;
The standerlings stood, not toppling,
In hummel-hum and glee.

He tiptoed from the musicroon,
Baton all gleam and gay;
"Come see!" he cried, "they keep the tune—
Hip-hip, tra-lah-tra-lay!"

"O timp-and-tum!" the elders sang,
"And cheery cymbal-ray!
Now bow your bow till rafters rang—
Huzzah! Hoorah! Hooray!"

poem:
The Mapwyrm

At chartfall, when the gridlines hummed,
the meridims were pale;
the legend-lamps were softly plumbed,
the towns lay mothlike, frail.

“Mark Mapwyrm, little mapling-heart—
fold-serpent of the plain;
it loops your northle clean apart
and sips your compass-brain.”

I buckled scaleblade, keen and clear,
and shouldered compass-spar;
packed pocket-lore against the drear,
and paced by crease and scar.

By Foldwold’s seam the atlas-briar
made stitch and paper-snap;
the coastlines hissed with saltish fire,
the hills wore contour-cap.

Then surged the Mapwyrm, vellum-mawed,
through contour-shadowed gloom;
its copper teeth were rivet-clawed,
its breath a papery plume.

My scaleblade sang a chartle-gale,
the compass-spar went ring;
I loosed its longitwinèd trail
and latitwirled its string.

It sighed a final meridim
and folded to a plane;
the creasewood hushed from rim to rim,
ink settled into grain.

To Elder Cartomere I came
with curl of crackled trail;
his joy went bright as legend-flame—
we danced the borderrail.

At chartrise then the gridlines purred,
the meridims grew hale;
the map lay open, road and word,
and towns un-moth from veil.

poem:
Ballad of Layover Bay

In Layover Bay the ramp-lamps sway
where timetide taps the piers;
The gategulls haggle the foam to gray
and tingle the waiting ears.

"Pack tight," quoth old Ticketock Tip,
and stow your yawns away;
The waitwinds nip with punctual whip,
beware the wide delay.

"Polish your patience, button your grin,
keep snacklets close at hand;
For dallysprays and loiterfins
are common in this strand."

I sloshed along the carousel kelp
through turnstile drifts of spray;
The snack-bar cliffs gave gingery help
to hearts that would delay.

Then whoomped a Baggage-bubblefish,
all carousel-striped and spry;
It flittered round my waiting dish
and winked a tarmac eye.

From under Loudhailer Bluffs it rose—
the Lay’n’Wait Wyrm uncurled;
With queue-scale plates and stampy toes,
it fogged the posting world.

I hefted my boarding-pass saber,
all perforate and keen;
It snipped the knots of humdrum labor
that clutch the in-between.

We jigged three jags, we looped and lagged,
the timetable beast did reel;
I poked its snoot, its stickers sagged—
it bonked a final peal.

Back past the snackulous dunes I ran,
where Ticketock Tip held sway;
He flapped his cap, a peppered fan,
"The lag is kept at bay!"

O claptious noon! Huzzah, hooray!
Let gategulls wheel and bray;
We drum the docks and shout our say—
bright luck to Layover Bay!

poem:
The Pixelwight

At glitch-o’-gloam the smearish panes
went flicker-soft and slow;
the rasterrime on window-mains
grew thick with afterglow.

Old tech-folk croaked in circuit lanes:
“Mind Pixelwight, ye know;
it spawns the curse called burn-in stains
and steals your panel’s glow.”

It loves the logos, corner-bit,
the ticker’s iron grin;
where pause-pip pets the screen a whit,
it breeds a ghost within.

I wound my saver-swirls to spin,
loosed pixle-winds to roam;
with dither-drifts and shuffle-skin
I tried to shake it home.

Out slunk the Pixelwight at last,
a glimmer-gnashing thing;
its teeth were tiny diode-blast,
its tongue a scanline-sling.

I raised my anti-burnish blade—
a strobelet-mending beam—
and through the smears of static shade
I cast a cleaving gleam.

It cracked; the ghostglyphs loosed their stain,
the menus’ scars uncurled;
the Pixelwight slid down the pane
and puddled from the world.

So let your pictures wander, dance;
let screens take night to sleep;
or burnibloom will, given chance,
set rasterroots too deep.

poem:
The Glimmerwheels of Monte Carlo

Glimmerbright the seaside night; the yachts hummed low with gloam,
and gilted domes went shimmer-shine above the sugared foam;
the chip-chime chirred, the rouleway purred, a whirry-whisking show—
oh Montecarlequinning lights, that bid the bold to go!

“Mind you,” croaked an auntied sage, “beware the spinnywog!
The house-edge has a nibble-bite that gnaws the braggart’s log.
Keep budget-buckles cinchy-tight; let whimsies not be guide;
and pack a plan, you lucklet—let patience be your stride.”

I primed my purse with portioned chips, in stacks of tidy snow,
I knotted will to wary wits and let the rashness go;
I ran a million jitter-jigs, in simulatronic breeze,
to sound the chanceful chaparral and seed the random seas.

Through baccarat and blinkle-slots I wended, soft and slow,
past dice that clacked like pebble-rain in crapsalicious flow;
the Rouléwock went whirr-purr-whirr, its grin a lacquered bowl,
and dealers dealt with silken hands, each eyebrow cool and droll.

I hedged my hedgy hedgerows, placed a pebble on the red,
then drifted light to black again, where riskling rumor led;
I martied not, nor tilt-tripped wild; I let the bellies roll,
and skimmed the skimmy edges of the whirligigging soul.

And when the glimmerwheel drew breath, a hushling breezed the room;
my number sprit-sprang sunrise-hot—fizzmirth and little boom;
a sprig of wins—not dragon-large, but jolly small and neat—
I scooped the sprangle-gleaming chips and danced away on feet.

Home down the Miramarry steps I skippled, grin aglow,
past tuxied sprites and moon-sweet sails that noddled to and fro;
“O fabjulune!” my auntie sang, “Hooraloo! Hooralay!
Did prudence guard your glimmer-purse and hubris keep at bay?”

I bowed and chimed, “Enough to toast the sea with bubbles bright;
and after that, to wander off before the biting night.
For Monte Carlo twinkleswitches hearts to folly’s brink—
but wiser whirls the wanderer who knows just when to wink.”

So glimmerbright the seaside stays; the yachts hum low with gloam;
beware the merry spinnywog and budget-button home;
take plan and poise; when fortune nods, don’t tarry till you rue—
then croon your luck and skippyskip, while waves go woo-woo-woo.

poem:
The Velvetwing Gloam

Gloamish hum in velvet wings;
the flats go flimmer-sway;
catwalks clink their copperlings,
and gel-ghosts smear the gray.

Cue-lights blink like beetle-eyes,
spike-tape stars the floor;
sandbags breathe their sandy sighs,
and props nap near the door.

Heed the Snickleswitch of cues,
the Lanternwyrm’s blue glow;
and shun, my friend, the Wingramph’s shoes
that creep and steal the show.

He hefted up a gobo-glaive
and donned his murmur-mask;
with whisperstep and actor-brave,
he sought the wingborn task.

Burble-budge! the Wingramph came
through drop and drape and rack;
with velvetrush and limelame,
and clapper-click-clack-clack.

Zip-zap! the gobo-glaive went arc,
through dust and rig and shade;
the Wingramph flung a curtainspark
that jittered jink and jade.

He cued the thunder-sheet to roar,
and rained the snow from flies;
the Wingramph stumbled stage-left, sore,
and bungled all its sighs.

Down drooped its hushy velvetsnout,
down fell its whisker-wings;
the ghostlight kept its single scout,
the prompt-bell softly rings.

Huzza-lilt filled the velvet lanes,
the spike-tape shone anew;
they lauded, with their cue-chains,
the brave of whisper-hue.

poem:
The Brunebutter Ballad

It was sizzly in the skillet-glade,
The melty motes were skreening;
All flickerflame and foamy braid,
With nutter-scent a-gleaning.

"Take heed, my cook! Beware the burn,
The black-bite, harsh and bristle;
Keep swirl and watch the whey to turn,
Hear milk-specks pop and whistle.

Turn low the fire, be spoonstead true,
Let frothlings flip and wander;
Keep hover-eye on amber hue,
And sniff the hazel yonder."

He gripped his whorlwood spoon in palm,
And faced the sputter-summer;
He stirred and stood in butter-calm,
A patient panward drummer.

And as he watched the pale go gold,
The flecks grew toastly-braver;
The foam sank down in rippled fold—
A nuttersome new flavor.

"Now tilt and lift the fleckling tide,
Then set it swift aside;
When amber hums, let scorchlings hide—
Be brisk, be burn-denied!"

He pulled it from the fire’s grin,
The Brunebutter, gleaming;
He poured it slow with grinny spin
On sage and mash a-dreaming.

With pan aloft he galumpled back,
Through doorway, proud and plucky;
"O buttersome day! O sizzling knack!"
They snortle-cheered so lucky.

poem:
Creep-thrum and the Nittlecreep

Blinver dusk was grivver-cold; the hedgerows hushlings stooped,
While snudgy moss in drumble folds along the flagstones looped;
The lampmoths sang in filament, all glimmer-green and deep—
And every gap and cobble-step went creep and creep and creep.

“Mind well the Nittlecreep, my sprout—the slow-toothed, velvet creep!
Its slipshade grin, its syrup-spin, its nuzzle-soft and steep.
Beware the ooze that smiles at you; beware the snaileye stare—
The creep that never leaps at all, but finds you unaware.”

I took my bramblestaff in hand, my kettle-lid for shield,
A jitterlight within my pack, best banishers I wield;
I muttered runes of shuffle-quick, of spurtle-step and sweep,
And ventured down the garden stones to parley with the creep.

It slouched from under stair and sill, a quilt of dusk and dew,
With swaying fringe of nettle-fur and button-eyes of blue;
Its feelstreels tapped the paving squares, its whisperwhiskers peep—
O murkling mild and many-miles: the Nittlecreep, the creep!

We bargained by the pump and pail; it hummed a honeyed drone,
It braided weeks around my boots and cinched them to the stone;
I stamped a stamp, I swirled my broom, I flickerflung a spark—
But creep is patient as a clock and sips the edges dark.

So I unspooled a scarlet thread and pegged the margins tight,
I chalked a ring of wakeful words and set my jitterlight;
The creature blinked, then slumped and slid, like pudding from a heap,
It slubbed away with slippered sway—the Nittlecreep, the creep.

Now keep your thresholds nimble-swept, your corners clear and bright,
Let nonsense songs be lantern-strong against the nibble night;
For not with fang nor rattleglaive, but with a steady keep,
We hearten halls and hedge the crawl of every hushborn creep.

poem:
The Borebright Awl

At twindle-time the leathers lay
all slumbly-brown along the stall;
The beeswax warmed to honey-day,
and on the peg winked Borebright Awl.

Bewatch the pricklenib, young sprout;
that sneaky beak can slip and maul!
Glove up thy mitts, be wise about,
and wax the twine before the awl.

He gripped the stindle-handle tight,
his braceboard set, his boot-to-be;
He marked the hide in candlelight,
and mutter-mused a cobble-glee.

Skrink-skrank the point went through the grain,
so nizzle-neat, no fray at all;
The loops like minnows laced the lane,
led twirly-twine behind the awl.

But skitter-snap! a sneaky skid—
the prickle-peck near pronged his paw!
He blemped and blinked at what he did,
and held his breath and humble awe.

Then steady-steady, bridle wrist;
keep true the bore, nor haste nor stall;
Let leather learn the moonish twist,
and let the thread go kiss the awl.

The bootlets rose, a burly pair,
with snoddish seams and twingle sprawl;
Their soles went plock on cobble air—
all born beneath the Borebright Awl.

He bobbed to Gran of cobbler clan
with bouncy grin and stitchy drawl:
“O brimmish boon, O merry man—
I tamed the pricklenibbing awl!”

She pranced and flung her apron wide:
“O jollijink! huzzu! hurawl!
Tonight we feast and boots will stride—
come dance, come dine, and praise the awl!”

poem:
The Thrumblewock and the Third-Rail Hum

When gloam was thick and switchlights plumed,
The tunnel sighed in trembleplum;
Through ballast-lilt and sleeper-fume
There drifted third rail hum.

“Mind, tram-born sprout, the Thrumblewock—
Its whiskers fizz with sparklum;
It drinks the dusk from bolt and block,
And teeth the third rail hum.

Shun too the Voltivore that skirls,
The scuttle-gnash, the Ohmish drum;
But most, beware the crackle-curls
That comb the third rail hum.”

He donned his insul-gauntlets tight,
His breaker-rod went clatter-plum;
He paced the ties by signal-light
To meet that third rail hum.

And while he mused by chalky stones,
Out slid, with zizzle-stuttered tongue,
The Thrumblewock on copper bones
To sip the spark among.

One zattle-snap! two crackle-thrangs!
The air went thick with stutter-rum;
He parried arcs and shoe-fang fangs
That nursed the third rail hum.

He cleaved a whirlig clamp-and-clout;
Its whiskers smoked to curdled gum—
The Thrumblewock gave one last spout
And swallowed down its hum.

“O neon noon! Huzzum! Huzzay!”
Cried elder-kin in metrolum.
“Come scrimble home and dance the day
Beside the soothed rail’s hum.”

When gloam unknots and switchlights bloom,

The Clatterphase

Paraplum and the Drizzlegnash

The plink-and-plunk of drapple drops through gabled gloamings flowed;
The flaggy lanes went splosh-a-spell; the chimneys coughed with spray,

But take the Paraplum,” he said, “and broll your fears away.”

I grasped the Paraplum by crook; its spine was sprung with gleam,
A ribbing star of shadowstuff, sewn tight with sunlit seam;
I snapped it wide—kerflap! kerflue!—a night within the day,

It sniffed the shade; it bit the brim; it gnurled a gusty bleat—
I twirled the Paraplum about; the splatters missed my feet;
With plash and clash and scuddleshank we wheeled in slither-spree,
Till snap! I snared its squishy snout and brollicuffed it free.

The gales un-gulped; the cloud-herds broke; the drizzle lost its gree;
The Drizzlegnash went gurgle-gone, a soppy skulking flea.
I folded up my Paraplum—click-click the spokes all sang—

Now murkish mizzles mumble less, though gutters gabble still;

the firstling desire-path.

the Turfgnash Grumple sprang;
its buckleplates and badgey hooves
went clinkle-clankle-clang.

between the cloverfoam.

the wishway slicked to clay.

a soft and certain keel.

and dusk-breeze combs the swath;
the world remakes its lawful buzz
around the thrumble-path.

a bumblesleek and gentle thing;
it wove the dawn in mufflemays

the Foggenwight hummed soft again.

The Burn‑inwock

At gloam‑o’‑clock the clicky keys were drumming soft and thin,
The cursors fizzled zigzag‑bright and stitched a glow‑grin in;
The widget‑wights went shimble‑sham through tabs of teal and tin,
While ghostlets grinned with fainty‑stain—the foretaste of burn‑in.

Heed, sprout, the Burn‑inwock: its ghosty jaws will grin;
Those bander‑bars and clingy glyphs that never quite give in.
Steer clear the Stucksy Pixel‑sprite, the Icon‑Grimp and kin,
And keep thy saver whirr‑a‑whirr, lest images burn in.

He hefted up his Ditherblade; for many ticks had been
The priming of the Saverclock and Shuffle‑shifting within;
He dimmed the glare to moonish‑ware, slid Nightshade Filter in,
Then hummed a lull to pixels all, to ward the wick of burn‑in.

He idled near the status trees and clicked a mousy rune,
When up from under toolbar fog there burbled bleep and din;
A stripèd thing with scorchy breath, a stare like noon‑at‑noon,

Its logo‑slats were welded wide, its afterglimmers thin,
It trailed a sash of menu‑bars all stampèd into skin;
It hissed in phosphor‑thistle tones, “I win, I stay, I pin,”
And smeared its grin across the grid—oh, sticky, slow burn‑in!

Flip‑flap! the Ditherblade went whisk; the jitter‑jutter spin,
The Saverclock kept shuffle‑steps; the pixels pranced within;
He swipe‑and‑shifted, pano‑drifted, cycled dark to dim,
Till bander‑bars fell flitter‑bits and vanished back within.

It gave a sputter‑sizzle sigh, a plastiglassy thin,
Then blinked to blank; the pane went pure, as river after rain;
He wrapped the screen in saver‑sheen and let night‑rest begin,
And back he went through sidebar lanes, with quiet, ghostless brain.

“And hast thou quelled the Burn‑inwock? Come, set the kettle in!
We’ll toast with cocoa‑amber foam the pixels fresh and clean;
Oh, gladsome day! hura‑hurree! No shadow‑glyphs remain—
Come dance the Scrollo‑reel with me, beneath a ghostless sheen.”

So mind the glow and pace thy gaze; let shufflemodes begin,
Let breaks and blanks and bedtime drift be daily woven in;
For thus we foil the ghosty glaze and keep our windows grin—
A merry screen, a merry eye, and none of that burn‑in.

The Againwyrm

Gleamgloom slid on thrumble hush; the twindle-branches bowed,
And whorlyweeds in wobble pits went burbling, loop-aloud;
All dapplemotes went ring-a-ree through hollow-vales of blue—
It seemed it had already seemed: the smell of déjà-dew.

“Mind thee the Againwyrm, child,” old Gransire murped and frowned;
“Its spiral stare eats yester-air and chews the nowness round.
It coils the path you mean to take with backwhirl, round-and-when;
It nibbles at your going forth and hands it back again.”

I fetched my yestersteelful blade, a twicesharp refrain,
And donned the helm of Remever, stitched with threads of Then;
I gripped a counterclockward haft of neveridle wood,
And paced the Perhapstree’s shadowbank where If and Maybe stood.

I waited through the tickletocks, the hush-a-when, the while,
Till dupplight folded overleaf in twice-remembered style;
A footfall fell, fell once-again, then fell where it had been—
And from the loopershade it slid: the Againwyrm, lean and green.

Its eyes were little spiraclaws that curled the future thin,
Its tongue went “Once! Again!” again, and wound where once had been;
Its scales were slick with everyet, its breath a circlune gust,
It wagged a tail of roundelay and lapped the path to dust.

No sooner had it hissed anew, I raised my echo-blade;
I swung a crosswise figure-eight, a cleaving promenade—
Snickersnap? Nay, rindlecrack! through coils of second-same,
I split the knot of nowness twice and out unlooped its name.

Down fell the twine of yesterday; the ground forgot to spin.
The Perhapstree stood perhapless; air turned crisp and thin.
I borne the felled Againwyrm’s head, still mouthing “Yet again,”
And strode to Gransire’s hearth of Once, now freshened into When.

“O loop-sprung joy!” he cry-whooped then, “O thrice-unwinding boon!
You’ve cut the knot the hours tied and chased away the rune.
Come sip the tea of Only-Now, let roundabout be through—”
And still I swear I heard the dusk say, “Have we done this too?”

Gleamgloom rose in thrumble hush; the twindle-branches bowed,
And whorlyweeds in wobble pits went burbling, soft and proud;
All dapplemotes went ring-a-roe through hollow-vales anew—
It seemed it had not seemed before—yet smelled of déjà-dew.

threw prinkish stars about the craft.

Through clötter-night and shingle-drift
he paced the lanes of hide and glue;
The skiver breeze went needle-swift,
and snurly moths in flutters flew.

Out from the strop-tree, whisper-wet,
the Thrumblegrin uncoiled its jaw;
A rimple-tail like thuttering net,
and clackclaws tapping rawk-rawk raw.

It blinked with button-borrel eyes—
two greeby lamps of nubbly lume—
And Finlo, bold in cobbler guise,
went prickety-prack to meet his doom.

He feinted left, he jinked to right,
then thrust the awl in stitcher’s arc;
A twizzle-turn, a braddle-bite,
and poke! the point found thrumble-mark.

The Thrumblegrin gave scrattle-yow,
leather-scented thunder broke;
It fratched and folded, dwindling now,
to naught but holes and drift of smoke.

Back to the bench he trundled home,
his awl-tip warm with workwell pride;
Old cobbles hummed in gristy loam,
and brimble-lanterns bobbed beside.

At frammil dusk the scrimble shaws
still whorl-and-whittle by the bench;
The awl keeps hush with bradbright jaws,
while mending songs un-scrieve the scrench.

prompt: Write a poem about creep in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
The Snickle-Creep

In grumbleglow the hedges leaned,
Besloshed with mist and thistle-sheen;
The snickle-creep, all shadow-creened,
Went snargling through the guddle-green.

“Mind, spryling, mind the Creep,” they said,
“It shimmles under cellar-stone;
It pats the ankle, winks the dread—
Go armed, go wise, and not alone.”

So I took up my glimmer-hook
And slung my bramble-buckle pack;
My tiddle-lamp, my courage-book,
A jammy bun for coming back.

I trudged the drindle-ditch and lane,
Where nettles hiss and pebbles peep;
The wind went winkles in the grain,
And somewhere near, I heard it creep.

It skreeked a smile with lanterns thin,
It sidled soft as falling soot;
Its whisper had a thistled grin,
Its fingers were a fidget-foot.

“Ho, cease your snickle, Creep!” I cried,
And plied my hook with thrum and sweep;
We twizzle-twined and tumble-skied,
Then swack! I snipped its sneaky creep.

The moon unbuttoned clouds to stare,
The hedges hummed a merry beep;
It skitter-shed its clingy glare,
And folded like a napkin-sleep.

I bore my brave and bun and tale
Back home through lanes of puddle-deep;
“Huzzah and skippaloo!” the hale
All shouted, “You uncrept the Creep!”

So mind, dear walkers, when it’s late,
When chimney-dimples drowse and weep,
Keep twindle-light and steady gait,
And never let the creepish creep.

poem:
The Wantward Way

Under hushmoss noon the stitle-sward
was frettled smooth with dew;
the hedgerows kept a keeper’s guard,
the signs all stern and true.

Hark, pipling sprig, to elder-say:
the Wantward Way will woo;
its nudgewinds sneck the proper way
and slip you thither through.

For out along the crosscut bend,
where footwish turns to flume,
there lairs the Wanderwych, my friend,
all glim with beckon-bloom.

It hums: “Go swerve the stinchy gate,
the tanglefence is slow;
take yearnstrait through the hushy late,
where grassblood learns to glow.”

We trod and trod till stompings pooled,
a tramplewhisp was born;
the croonhedge leaned, the slick-sedge schooled,
and shinpath showed at morn.

And still, at dusk, the Wanderwych
new wantlets names by name;
the ground remembers every switch
and curves our days the same.

So mind your map and foot, dear sprig,
when thitherish urges yawn;
for Wantward Ways grow big, grow big,
from one small trodlet drawn.

prompt: Write a poem about morning fog in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
Mizzlewisp Morning

It was the mizzletide; the lanes
were murkled, meek, and low;
the hedgerows wore their pearlèd grains,
and cockerels crowed too slow.

"Beware the foglings, sproutling mine,"
said Gran with furrowed brow;
"they snorfle-drift and snuggle-spine—
so keep your tucker now.

Bring blinker-lamp and snicket-staff,
and zip your zodden coat;
the mizzle mumbles, odd as chaff,
and nibbles at your throat."

I wound my snither-scarf about
my chatter-chin and nose;
I packed a bun and ventured out
where mizzlewisping goes.

The fog came fuzzle-puzzlewise,
a fluther, thick and pale;
it sworled along in glozzled sighs
and blurred the gate and rail.

From gutter-gloom a Fog-a-loo
went thrumple, soft and soft;
it lapped the fence and hedgerow too
and muffled up the loft.

I whirled my snicket-staff askew,
and dingled bell and sang;
"Begone, you drifty, drabbly stew!"
my braveheart drumlet rang.

It dwindled into snorfs and threads,
it thimled up the lane,
till dawnlet tipped the chimney-heads
and gilt the window-pane.

Back home I skipped with dew-bright boots,
and crusty loaf in sack;
"O hallaloo!" cried mugs and flutes—
"our mizzle's turned its back!"

Now ends the mizzlewisp; the lanes
unmurkle, bright and new;
the hedgerows shake their pearlèd grains—
sing hallaloo, halloo!

poem:
Third-Rail Thrumble

Down-tunnel where the dripply lamps
do glisk and gloom through iron scum,
the sleepers crouch, the ballast cramps,
and all is thrung with third rail hum.

Mind-gap and sheath your fingerlings,
for sparkers make a snicker-plum;
with copper whisk and whisper-wings
stalks Voltivor, the Raildrum.

I took my stave of wooden proof,
my amber lamp with saffron bloom;
I tiptoed by the dripper-roof
to where it purred—third rail hum.

It trembled low, it thrimmed it high,
a fizzlewhirr, a brackletune;
then Voltivor unshuttered eye
and zampled forth in zingazoon.

Its jaws were forks of nickel gnash,
its whiskers hissed with ohmy-glow;
I held my distance—no brash dash—
and let the humward currents flow.

It cooed a carglow lullaby,
then swirled back down the tunnel-plum;
and all the rails went shiver-sly,
still singing, singing: third rail hum.

poem:
The Sprocketwock

In dimble hour the silver rolls
Did whirr and whumble-tune,
The sprocketlings through velvet backs
Went clitter-clatter soon;
All mimbly-gray the bokeh bloomed,
A lens—moon-mouthed—would grin,
The redlamp gloamed in darkroom womb
And beckoned us within.

“Keep safe,” quoth elder Photo-pap,
“The Sprocketwock beware!
Its jangle-fangs can shred a frame
To tassel-ribbon air.
Shun Leak-o-Light, that tricksy bird,
And Dustygrubs that scratch;
And never sneeze in loading-time—
It spoils a tender batch.”

He grasped the clickersnapper-box,
All leatherette and brass,
He primed the winder—shnick-a-whirr!—
To let the first frame pass;
He set the stop to f/8 clean,
The time to one-two-five,
ASA four-oh-oh he chose
To let the shadows thrive.

Through alleys neon-slick he crept
To stalk the flicker-thing,
Past cinema ghosts and lamplit posts
Where silverlings take wing;
He paused beside a tripod tree
And in his viewdream peered,
While chemistry of nerves and night
Made all the hush grow weird.

Soft from the billboard bramble-vale
The Snapperwock drew near;
Its shutter-lids went click-a-bit—
A tick he well could hear;
Its motorwind went whiffling-burr
With burble-whirly bound,
And beetle-beaked a lenshood bobbed
In circles, round and round.

Click-snick! the curtains stitched the light;
The aperture went blink;
He held his breath a whisker’s width
Upon the focus brink;
He wound again—ka-chunk, ka-chunk—
Prepared another pass,
And trapped a phantom city-bird
In silver-salted glass.

He sealed the reel in darkness black
With fingertip and feel,
He danced the chemicoil gavotte:
The soup, the stop, the seal;
Dev bath to sway, then lemon-stop,
And fixer, stout and stout,
He rinsed and swished the silver skin
Till ghosty shapes came out.

He hung the negatives to drip,
Each frame a glimmer-raft,
Grainlings hummed in pebble-drift,
A crackle-moony craft;
He proofed a tidy contact sheet—
Small midnight-ticking clocks—
And laughed to see the captured beast
Within its sprocket-box.

“Have you unjammed the Sprocketwock?”
Cried Photo-pap, astir.
“Didst tame its grunchy grinding teeth
And bid its jangle purr?”
“O snapful day!” the youngster sang,
“Clackoo! Clackay! Huzza!”
He waved the glossy glazzle-sheets—
“Behold! Hurray! Hurray!”

In dimble hour the silver rolls
Still whirr and whumble-tune,
The sprocketlings through velvet backs
Go clitter-clatter soon;
All mimbly-bright the bokeh blooms,
The lens wears moonish grin—
And pictures purr in shoebox dens:
Come, spool the dream again.
